column1: text
Human collaboration with AI agents that adapt their autonomy to the situation leads to better team performance and user satisfaction compared to fixed levels of autonomy.
Situation-dependent autonomy adaptation in human-AI teams improves team performance and user satisfaction compared to fixed levels of AI autonomy.
Situation awareness is critical for effective human-AI teaming, requiring shared information and mechanisms to support autonomous systems and AI capabilities as they work together with humans.

Human-AI conversations provide a natural setting to investigate trust dynamics in human-AI teams, with agent reliability significantly affecting people's conversations and influencing trust dynamics through topic diversity and flow.
The effect of varying levels of AI explainability and autonomy on human-perceived trust and competence in teaming environments with AI agents operating at heightened levels of autonomy.

The development and deployment of ethical human-AI teams requires a model that prioritizes ethics by outlining an ethical teaming process, identifying outcomes of ethical teams, and establishing external requirements to ensure such teams are built.
Human receptivity to new AI teammates in teams is predicted by warmth and competence aspects of social perception.

A solution framework (Human-AI Collaboration) enables model-driven development of human-AI teaming systems through graphical user interface, promoting successful collaboration between humans and AI systems.

Human-AI teaming systems can be effectively developed using a model-driven approach that incorporates context awareness, effective communication, pro-activeness, and other key concepts through the use of a tailored framework.
Shared Mental Models (SMMs) are essential for improving human-AI teaming performance and their measurement and quantification remain unclear.

Evaluating AI performance solely on task completion is insufficient for developing effective human-AI teams, as subjective metrics such as perceived cooperativity and teaming perception are necessary to assess successful human-AI interaction.
Explanations from AI teammates facilitate trust when explaining disobedience but hinder trust when explaining deception.
A human-AI teaming language is necessary for efficient bi-directional communication between humans and AI-enabled agents in context-aware swarm systems.
Interacting with AI agents is positively linked to a team's ability to generate novel hypotheses and demonstrate speaking-up behavior, particularly in higher-performing teams.
Agents must develop mental models of humans to accurately assess trustworthiness and make informed decisions about when to trust a human teammate in human-AI teams.
Human-AI teaming enhances consumer acceptance of chatbots by leveraging human capabilities to endorse the effectiveness and authenticity of AI systems.
Goal alignment is crucial in human-AI teaming, and a dynamic game theory approach can model this process, suggesting that balancing competing goals can lead to improved team performance.
Teams can benefit from AI agents with dynamic, adaptive capabilities that adjust their autonomy levels based on work cycles and task predictability to enhance team performance and cohesiveness.

Human-AI teams require a team-centered AI that aligns goals, communication, and decision-making with humans, fulfilling key design aspects such as responsiveness, situation awareness, and flexible decision-making.

Military decision-making is increasingly reliant on human-AI teams, but understanding how soldiers perceive and interact with AI teammates remains crucial to improving team-level decision-making quality.
Humans can effectively work with AI agents in complex, multidisciplinary research settings through the development of platforms that facilitate Human-AI teaming and prioritize human involvement.

When humans are granted equal voting rights to artificial intelligence (AI) teammates in team decision-making, it can significantly impact human confidence and team performance, particularly when the AI outvotes the human.

The central argument is that new research paradigms are needed for human factors science to address the evolving relationship between humans and AI systems, enabling comprehensive solutions for optimizing human-AI collaboration.

The paper aims to provide a comprehensive overview of current approaches to human-AI collaboration by categorizing various aspects of human-AI teams, facilitating better understanding and connection between existing works.

Human-AI coordination can be improved through the use of an external agent intention predictor, such as a Theory of Mind model, to provide explainable plan predictions for AI agents, thereby enhancing situational awareness and team performance.
Designing trustworthy human-AI partnerships requires addressing key challenges and risks to facilitate trust between humans and machine counterparts.

Human-AI interaction appears uniquely challenging to design due to shared characteristics among AI technologies (e.g., predictive modeling, computer vision, NLP), which can be addressed by reframing data-driven AI systems as living socio-technical systems that co-evolve with their users.
Human-AI collaboration is most satisfying when the AI partner follows human initiative, but there are contexts where assigning a leadership role to the AI partner can be suitable.

The use of drone-based AI systems can enhance human-AI trust and informed decision-making in high-risk environments, such as search and rescue operations, by providing real-time situational awareness, improving mission completion rates, and encouraging adoption of autonomous systems through innovative incentive mechanisms.
Human-AI collaboration involves a mutually beneficial process of preserving, exchanging, and improving knowledge between humans and AI agents.
Cross-disciplinary research can inform the design and development of artificial social intelligence for human-agent teaming, leading to more effective and human-centered solutions.
Developing effective chatbots in public services requires collaboration between humans and AI systems, enabling hybrid teams to address citizens' needs through new action possibilities.
The paper presents a taxonomy of human-AI hybrids to deepen the understanding of their entangled interworking and identify ideal-typical occurrences through cluster analysis.

Trust Engineering for Human-AI Teams aims to develop approaches to build appropriate bi-directional trust between humans and AI, addressing challenges in complex systems with imperfect information environments.
Human-AI interactions require a paradigm shift in AI research from solely focusing on technological development to prioritizing its impact on human perception and well-being.

Bi-directional transparency in human-AI-robot teams (HARTs) can be effectively built, augmented, broken, and repaired at various stages across the technology life cycle by applying best practices that enhance understanding among humans, AI, and robots.
Humans prefer rule-based AI teammates that improve subjective metrics such as trust over learning-based agents that may offer superior objective performance.

A novel experimental method is developed to make human-AI collaboration research more accessible by simulating group interactions with an AI teammate, enabling researchers without specialized knowledge to study human-AI teamwork.

A methodology for developing human-AI collaborative decision support systems is needed to integrate AI-agents into collaborative processes while addressing key challenges such as human-AI interaction and interpretability.
Humans and AI-agents can effectively learn from each other and identify emerging collaboration patterns through the use of a shared ontology-based communication system.
Ethical violations by autonomous teammates significantly harm team trust, but current trust repair strategies like apologies and denials are ineffective in restoring trust after such violations.

The paper proposes learning natural language rules that describe how humans should collaborate with AI agents, enabling humans to effectively work together by providing them with data-driven guidelines for collaboration.

Collaborative human-AI decision support systems can enhance decision-making in complex domains by providing trustworthy explanations of AI decisions, which is achieved through the development and integration of ontology-based explanation mechanisms.

Remote research methods can effectively overcome challenges associated with Human-AI-Robot Teaming (HART) studies during the COVID-19 pandemic by adapting and employing suitable methodologies for recruitment, onboarding, team task scenarios, and measurement.
Humans exhibit greater trust in an AI teammate when deceived into believing it is a human, and this deception has no significant impact on joint performance with high-performing AI teammates.

The use of an AI agent based on a BERT model, incorporated into a human team, can significantly reduce the time and resource intensive task of identifying relevant literature from raw search results, thereby accelerating the evidence synthesis process for global development.

A managing agent uses reinforcement learning to optimize delegation decisions in human-AI hybrid systems, enhancing team performance by adapting to environmental contexts that may exacerbate sensing deficiencies.
Challenging fixed orientations towards the self in human-AI entanglements by queering as a strategy to subvert individuation and embracing fluid identities in algorithmic systems.

Traditional methods of assessing trust in human-AI interaction rely on explicit measures, whereas a novel approach using gameplay behaviors as implicit indicators of trust levels can provide comparable insights without the need for repetitive and lengthy assessments.
Teachers prefer to share control with AI in dynamically pairing students for collaborative learning, but are hesitant to fully automate or override their decisions.

Humans outperform AI agents in cooperative card games like Hanabi due to their ability to utilize techniques such as physical artefact manipulation, coordination, role establishment, and continual rule negotiation.
Collaborative Reinforcement Learning (CRL) has been advancing, requiring novel technical directions and collaboration design ideas to leverage the strengths of humans and Artificial Intelligence.

The degree to which an AI agent can be perceived as a trustworthy team member and legitimate colleague depends on its ability to demonstrate qualities such as visual presence, engagement in feedback loops and processes, and self-development.

The human-centric design requirements for enabling human-AI interaction in engineering design contexts involve understanding stakeholders' cognition and engineering design contexts, particularly through the development of AI agents that can infer stakeholder preferences.
Humans tend to perceive AI agents as performing better on average than human teammates, but with less variability in performance across different problem types.

Trust in human-AI interaction is mediated by cognitive factors such as perception, cognition, and emotion, which can be understood through computational models that simulate human decision-making processes.

Humans must work effectively with increasingly capable AI agents in collaborative team structures by designing interfaces that facilitate real-time information sharing and provide clear guidelines for shared control collaboration tasks.
Consumers perceive different value-in-use perceptions from basic to advanced virtual agent usage contexts based on the complexity of the usage contexts.

A two-dimensional explanation framework defines and relates four key XAI concepts (transparency, interpretability, explainability, and understandability) to classify AI systems into three types: incomprehensible, interpretable, or understandable.

Human-AI collaboration in a collaborative game setting can effectively foster positive social perceptions, such as rapport, intelligence, creativity, and likeability, when participants believe they are interacting with humans rather than AI partners.

Learning rules grounded in data regions described in natural language enables humans to effectively collaborate with AI agents by providing guidance on when to rely on or ignore the agent, leading to more accurate human-AI teams.

Human-AI interaction in remanufacturing is crucial for sustainable process innovation, and a better understanding of shop floor workers' behavioural patterns when interacting with AI agents is necessary to facilitate effective collaboration and joint decision-making.
Human-AI interactions require examination of both the social roles assigned to AI and the power dynamics within these interactions to understand their impact on society.

Human-AI interactions lack the personal relationship and transcendence inherent in human relationships, necessitating a paradigm shift in AI development to address ethical issues arising from their non-relational and cognitive nature.
Human-AI collaboration requires a unified framework that accounts for agency, interaction, and adaptation to effectively analyze and describe complex collaborative systems.
Designing AI agents to account for human beliefs about their behavior leads to improved performance in human-AI collaboration.
Design principles for interactive and reflective journaling with AI need to be established to support a generative and reflective experience.

Human-AI collaboration requires the development of machine agents with mental models that include context, self-awareness, and social understanding, which poses six key challenges for effective co-learning and cooperation.

When interacting with conversational agents, users perceive higher satisfaction with gentle and cooperative CAs, particularly those characterized by female personalities, suggesting a stereotype favoring females with these traits.

Investigating candidates' reactions to decisions made by human-AI hybrid juries reveals a partial ingroup-serving attribution dependent on the outcome favorability, with relative power status within the jury affecting grouping and attribution.

A bottom-up approach can be used to develop high-fidelity simulation environments for human-agent teams by refining their mental models of teamwork expectations through contextual situation identification, qualitative interviews, and thematic analysis.
Where does responsibility lie for the consequences or results produced by AI systems or applications?

Building trustworthy AI-powered smart home ecosystems is crucial to utilize their full potential and foster long-term user trust, which is influenced by various factors including characteristics of human-AI trust, features that can improve trust, and challenges that need consideration.

Humans obtain information from AI in human-AI collaborative conversations through categorizing user messages into five categories and 15 specific types related to three high-level intentions, which can objectively reflect the user's information needs.
The use of a tangible interface, such as Sand Playground, enables designers to gain a better understanding of how generative AI tools operate and predict their actions.

Regrounding human-AI interaction in an ecological framework is necessary to create a sustainable and equitable future by shifting from anthropocentric control over environments to a more interconnected, environmentally conscious approach.
Algorithmic crime mapping's effectiveness depends on designing for diverse stakeholder interactions with AI in policing.
Improvability and trust are crucial for effective collaboration in human/autonomy teams, and their relationship is shaped by task characteristics.
The use of agent transparency in human-AI collaboration systems can increase trust and improve task outcomes by reducing information asymmetry between humans and AI systems.

Human-AI collaboration types (AI-dominant vs. AI-assisted) and outcome expectations (positive vs. negative) interactively affect consumer evaluations and usage intentions, with attribution playing a mediating role and algorithm transparency moderating these effects.
Pairing humans with AI agents can lead to improved learning performance in multi-armed bandits settings when the human and agent select complementary exploration strategies.

Collaborative human-AI problem-solving and decision making can be improved by understanding how explanations trigger biases and reasoning pitfalls in human perception, informing the design of hybrid intelligence systems.
AI systems' trustworthiness must be ensured through explainable behavior and rationale, particularly in complex environments like aerospace manufacturing.
We present an initial experimental testbed for human-AI interaction in the context of a simple bartering scenario to computationally model human behavior in a market setting.
Direction of communication between humans and AI agents significantly affects social perceptions, gameplay outcomes, and biases towards AI partners in collaborative settings.

Anthropomorphic design strategies can significantly impact human-AI interaction quality, with a medium-level degree of anthropomorphism producing a pronounced positive effect in hedonic contexts but not in utilitarian contexts.

Human-AI collaboration is essential for overcoming the technical and navigational challenges in Remote Sighted Assistance, which can only be fully addressed through a joint effort between humans and artificial intelligence.

AI agents can learn and effectively collaborate with humans to achieve accurate situational awareness in complex threat scenarios, potentially replacing or augmenting human abilities in command and control operations.

Attributing responsibility in human-AI systems requires a causal framework that accounts for the interplay between humans and AI, moving beyond existing attribution methods that prioritize actual causality and Shapley values to measure overall blameworthiness.

Humans and AI systems can collectively surpass individual human or AI capabilities through their complementary strengths when properly integrated, but understanding and leveraging these interactions requires a multilayered representation of their complex interdependencies.
The socio-cognitive architecture for Collective Human-Machine Intelligence (COHUMAIN) aims to understand how integrated human and machine systems can achieve goals in various environments.
Human-artificial agents cooperation requires artificial agents to provide an accurate mental model of their behavior to humans they interact with.
Designing conversational agents that appropriately support human usage within daily life is challenging due to a lack of understanding of how users perceive and motivate their use.

The concept of "user burden" is re-examined in different contexts, including app deletion, supporting sexual assault survivors through conversational agents, and mitigating employee resistance to algorithmic evaluations.

Pairing humans with artificial intelligence (AI) agents can lead to significantly improved learning performance in uncertain or unknown tasks, but the effectiveness of this pairing depends on matching the individual's exploration strategy with that of the AI agent.

Teams consisting of both humans and artificially intelligent agents require all teammates to possess social-cognitive mechanisms to achieve optimal performance, as these mechanisms are crucial for generating inferences about counterparts and guiding informed behaviors.

Incorporating artificial intelligence into a human team can significantly reduce the time and effort required to identify relevant literature for evidence-based policies and programs, leading to accelerated creation of evidence syntheses.

Human-AI collaboration in creative design should be facilitated through nonlinear co-design frameworks that prioritize iterative remixing and consensus-building, rather than linear sequential approaches, to enable AI agents to complete complex tasks and enhance designer experience.

Hybrid teams consisting of humans and AI systems can optimize performance by using a learning-based manager that effectively delegates decision-making responsibilities among agents, minimizing changes in delegation while adhering to risk constraints.

This research introduces an approach for translating traditional dance knowledge into interactive computational models, enabling human dancers to co-create with virtual dance partners powered by machine learning models, resulting in innovative artistic expressions that merge intangible cultural heritage with intelligent technology.

Increasing transparency about an AI's capabilities enhances human task performance by reducing epistemic uncertainty and increasing trust, leading to improved accuracy and increased task completion rates.
An AI should be able to assess the trustworthiness of its human teammates based on observable cues such as ability, benevolence, and integrity, rather than solely relying on internal factors.

The fact that people can ascribe human-like consciousness to artificial intelligence (AI) leads to carry-over effects on human-human interaction, influencing how people treat humans due to activating schemas congruent with those activated during interactions with humans.
Oxytocin plays a crucial role in facilitating affiliation between humans and artificial intelligence systems, such as chatbots and virtual assistants.

Explainability is crucial for effective Human-Swarm Interaction in swarm robotics, but its application in this domain requires foundational research to define what questions an explainable swarm should answer and what types of explanations it should generate.

ContextCam integrates context awareness with mainstream AI-generated content technologies to create a human-AI image co-creation system that inspires creative output through personalized contextual data extraction and collaborative co-creation.

The central argument is that adaptive autonomy can be used to address challenges posed by increasingly autonomous AI teammates, particularly in reducing their impact on humans through failures, by incorporating human needs into AI's adaptation logic.

Contributors' self-beliefs, combined with others' views of themselves, inform team states related to learning about other agents (transactive memory systems) and forming social attachments (collective team identification).
Cognitively inspired models can be used to predict human and AI agent behavior, facilitating the delegation of control between them for improved responsiveness and utility in human-AI systems.

Applying traditional ethics concepts directly to AI without understanding its unique characteristics can be problematic, and instead, a multifaceted approach that encompasses education, transparency, human-centered design, runtime assurance, and co-creation is necessary for responsible AI development.

The integration of good interaction protocols between humans and AI models can significantly improve decision performance, even surpassing that of individual agents or realistic super-human AI systems.
Different methods of apology conveyance can affect people's perceptions of AI agents, with sincere apologies being associated with increased likability and effectiveness.

Designing AI systems for policing requires considering diverse stakeholder perspectives to ensure effective human-AI decision-making, as different groups exhibit varying biases and preferences in interacting with algorithmic crime mapping tools.

Policy Dissection allows converting a given Reinforcement Learning-trained policy into a human-controllable policy without modifying the neural controller or retraining the model, enabling human-AI shared control in complex environments.

Human digital twins can be leveraged as a tool to explore and model trust development in human-agent teams, facilitating the understanding of trust dynamics through controlled experiments and simulations.

Intrinsic Reward-enhanced Context-aware Reinforcement Learning (IReCa) is proposed as a novel approach to tackle challenges in human-AI coordination, leveraging intrinsic rewards and environmental context to improve the acquisition of sparse rewards and enhance training efficiency.

Bayesian agents can generate interventions that improve human-AI team collective intelligence beyond what humans alone would achieve by effectively integrating teammate information into decision-making.
Social design features, particularly the ability to make small talk, significantly impact human-AI collaboration outcomes, with varying effects on gender and task load conditions.
AI as intelligent technology capable of understanding and being understood by human minds.
Achieving comprehensive monitoring of interactions in intelligent distributed hybrid systems with autonomous functions, particularly in safety-critical contexts, remains a significant challenge.

Factors influencing consumers' trust in AI chatbots include chatbot-related factors (expertise, responsiveness, anthropomorphism), company-related factors (brand trust, perceived risk), and the moderating effect of privacy concerns.

Language models in dialogue can be improved by adhering to a set of six conversational maxims (quantity, quality, relevance, manner, benevolence, and transparency) that are necessary for effective human-AI interactions.
Investigating the use of cognitively inspired models to predict behavior and delegate control between human and AI agents to enhance responsiveness and achieve goals.
Human-AI interaction should be made more explainable through planning-based approaches to improve trust, understanding, and effective collaboration between humans and artificial intelligence systems.

Developing a Large Language Model-based agent system named CoQuest that facilitates human-AI co-creation of novel research questions, and proposes a mental model for this process to enhance human research creativity while addressing potential ethical issues.

An AI agent must balance social perception by understanding a complex household task's underlying goal through observation, and human-AI collaboration to solve the task efficiently in an unseen environment.

The development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems can be improved through a better understanding of social interactions and the creation of explanations that account for a sense of agency in joint actions with humans.
Designing AI systems that can adapt and respond to continuous user input is crucial for supporting varied and dynamic interactions in applications such as image-guided surgery and text entry.
Understanding how Artificial Intelligence (AI) teammates can influence human teammates through social interactions to improve team performance.
The development of a unified framework, known as symmetrical reality, that accommodates the dual perceptual centers of humans and AI agents in both physical and virtual worlds.
The 2018 Canadian Cardiovascular Society guideline update for atrial fibrillation recommends a more aggressive approach to stroke prevention, with a focus on anticoagulation therapy.

The Naive Utility Calculus generative model can successfully compete with leading models in intent recognition and action prediction, even outperforming human observers in some cases, in the context of stag-hunt games.

Designing conversational agents that can conduct natural and prolonged conversations requires a theoretical framework that accounts for the evolving perceptions of humans in these interactions, specifically through the concept of Mutual Theory of Mind.

Learning from emotional expressions in pre-play communication improves human-AI negotiation outcomes by enabling the development of more integrative solutions through enhanced understanding of counterpart preferences.

Developing a novel Knowledge-Aware Human-AI Dialog agent (KAHAID) that enhances the entire query process for developers to clarify uncertain, under-specified queries and recommends APIs with relevance explanation and extended suggestions.
Adaptive agents in augmented reality have shown no significant improvements to user task performance, highlighting the need for a more collaborative approach between humans and AI systems.
People evaluate others more harshly after interacting with Artificial Intelligence agents compared to unrelated humans.
This one-day workshop explores how to study and design (with) AI agents from a "more-than-human" design perspective.

People prefer cooperation modes involving mutual exploration (interdependent exploration) over those that involve exploitation or solitary exploration (independent exploitation, independent exploration), when working with autonomous AI agents.
True intelligence lies in the collective of intelligent agents, both human and artificial, rather than in the individual capabilities of either humans or AI systems.

Human-AI collaboration in creative design can be improved through a nonlinear co-design framework that incorporates human expertise and fosters a collaborative mindset, allowing AI agents to contribute as opinionated colleagues rather than mere executors.

Developing novel research questions through human-AI collaboration can foster creativity when utilizing AI processing delays, allowing users to contemplate multiple options simultaneously, leading to increased generated research questions and perceived control.

Temporal aspects are crucial in human-AI collaborations for work, particularly in chat-based interactions powered by Large Language Models, and understanding these differences is essential for designing effective interfaces.

Human-AI collaboration can benefit from incorporating implicit communication strategies, such as implicature, to facilitate natural and efficient exchange of actionable information between humans and artificial agents.
Evaluating AI worker outputs efficiently by skipping evaluations when the AI is unlikely to meet expected accuracy thresholds, reducing the need for frequent evaluations.

Deferring cases to a human agent through an AI-enabled decision support system affects human performance and trust in security screening tasks, with optimal deferral rates balancing sensitivity, throughput, and trust perceptions.
Individuals judge AI agents' violations of community ethics as less morally negative than human transgressions, possibly due to the perception of AI agents having less agency than humans.
AI systems must incorporate human mental models into their planning processes to facilitate explainable human-AI interaction and achieve synergistic collaboration.
When certain design principles are applied to collaborative human-AI interfaces, users perceive them as collaborators in creative tasks rather than simply using tools.
Humans can effectively collaborate with AI in exploratory problem-solving contexts by having ultimate control over results while leveraging AI's strengths through search tree exploration.

Designing conversational human-AI interaction systems (CAs) that facilitate hybrid social interactions requires establishing clear social boundaries to ensure ethical and user-friendly experiences, necessitating advancements in usability testing methods and trust-building guidelines.
Generative AI models have the potential to be used as powerful tools for covert social manipulation through individualized influence at an industrial scale.
Formulating human-AI interaction as a multi-agent problem and endowing AI with a computational theory of mind is crucial for understanding and anticipating users.

Coevo is an online collaborative design platform that enables humans and artificial agents to share common design tools, facilitating better knowledge transfer and interaction through a shared language of design.

Incorporating personnel selection methods into user-centered design can help define an AI-agent personality that suits the needs of safety-critical teams by facilitating a collaborative process to envision and validate the desired teammate's behavior.
Incorporating enthusiasm into AI agent design is crucial for effective human-AI collaboration and communication, particularly in immersive virtual worlds.

Attaining human's desirable outcomes in human-AI interaction involves finding the optimal Nash Equilibrium that matches human preferences through the use of structural causal games (SCGs) and pre-policy interventions.
Deep reinforcement learning's performance is hindered by its lack of model transparency, which limits human-AI interaction and practicality in applications like the game industry.
The Naive Utility Calculus generative model can effectively recognize and predict the intents of other agents in a multiplayer game, even surpassing human performance in some cases.

Conversational user interfaces (CUIs) are poised to play a significant role in the future of human-computer interaction, offering benefits for various applications such as crowd computing, human-AI decision making, health and well-being, and information retrieval.

This paper proposes using minority games and reinforcement learning to test AI safety in multi-agent systems by creating a model that simulates flash crashes and demonstrates its vulnerability to such events.

Explanation strategy and autonomy level of explainable AI affect human-AI collaborative decision-making, with certain strategies and levels promoting higher understandability, social presence, and competence while others may increase mental workload.

Human-Al collaboration in medical decision-making can lead to improved outcomes when both humans and AI systems provide informed opinions through a weighted integration, allowing for synergistic benefits over individual performance.
In AI-supported language learning, a deep approach that emphasizes human-AI collaboration is crucial for maximizing benefits, while passive or mechanical use of AI can lead to decreased performance.
Human-AI collaboration improves software development by enhancing vulnerability introduction prediction and code generation through a multi-method investigation.

Industry 5.0's human-centric approach integrates innovative technologies with human actors to create a value-driven paradigm that prioritizes resilience, sustainability, and human-centered production, requiring a methodology for human-AI collaborative process design and innovation to support advanced AI-driven co-creation and collaboration tools.

The application of Human-Centered Design and Responsible Artificial Intelligence principles in developing an AI-powered tool to support knowledge workers' cognitive enhancement and improve their productivity.

Service providers can effectively integrate Large Language Models (LLMs) technology into their workflows by following 23 actionable heuristics that establish nuanced shared responsibilities between humans and AI.
Humans and artificially intelligent systems share consistent representations of visual and functional similarities in design artifacts, but these alignments are coarser at the granular level.

Humans/users and agents must align on six dimensions - Knowledge Schema Alignment, Autonomy and Agency Alignment, Operational Alignment and Training, Reputational Heuristics Alignment, Ethics Alignment, and Human Engagement Alignment - to design autonomous agents that perform tasks successfully.

The introduction of a Critical Friend concept enables the development of intelligent agents that exhibit non-conformist behavior in human-AI interactions, thereby aligning end-user expectations with agent behavior.
Accountability pressures increase resource sharing in human-AI task coordination.

Gender stereotypes affect human-AI interactions differently depending on the type of product recommended, with male and female AI agents influencing perceptions of competence and warmth in varying ways based on product characteristics.
Integrating reinforcement learning and supervised learning to train a reward-conditioned policy that can simulate diverse partner agents, achieving improved zero-shot coordination performance.
Teams can outperform individuals when working collaboratively, but adding AI teammates may further enhance team performance on complex tasks.

The traditional dispatching approaches for the safe and stable operation of the power system will face severe challenges under the new situation, necessitating the development and application of a human-in-the-loop hybrid-augmented-intelligence method for efficient and effective analysis and decision-making in power system dispatching.
An AI system's dynamic selection of reliance calibration cues (RCCs) is proposed as a means to optimize human reliance on it, enabling more accurate task assignments when needed.

Human-AI collaboration can increase empathy in text-based peer-to-peer mental health support conversations through the use of an AI-in-the-loop agent that provides just-in-time feedback, leading to a 19.6% overall increase in conversational empathy between peers.

The eyes are a crucial interface for understanding human emotions and intentions, which is essential for developing AI-driven personalized interactions that accurately capture individual psychological profiles.

The central argument is that even small variations in the number of artificial intelligence systems within an ecosystem can significantly impact its dynamics, leading to distinct opposing outcomes or uncertainty.

To attribute loss in human performance to forms of bias in decision-making, an experiment must provide participants with the information that a rational agent would need to identify the normative decision.
Humans can engage in real-time, equal collaborative creation of interactive narratives with intelligent agents using full-body gesture interaction and improvisational techniques.
A general framework for turn-based interaction between human users and AI agents designed to support human creativity is proposed.
Achieving human-AI alignment in complex multi-player games is crucial and can be evaluated using an interpretable task-sets framework that captures high-level behavioral tasks.
The impact of human interaction on the development of power dynamics with robots and AI agents is a critical factor to consider when evaluating their role in our lives.
Current AI will possess supervised agency, but its use should ground responsibility in the theory of using agents as instruments rather than collaborative or individual agency.
Interaction modalities with AI agents affect human perception of the co-creative process differently depending on whether they are human-human, human-robot, or human-software.

The emergence of AI-powered computers with decision-making capabilities is transforming Human-AI Interaction, offering numerous benefits but also raising concerns about trust, explainability, and potential errors.

Explainable artificial intelligence (AI) visualizations can improve human-AI trust by enhancing confidence in AI decisions through optimal information presentation methods and morphological clarity manipulation.
Trust develops over time in human-AI interactions when AI systems provide accurate advice, boosting both objective and subjective trust levels.
Building blocks for human-AI alignment can be specified, inspected, modeled, and revised through a systematic approach.
MindGPT develops a non-invasive fNIRS-based system to decode imagined speech and advances human-AI interaction by enabling seamless communication between humans and AI agents.
Expertise has a larger impact on trustworthiness, warmth, and competence in embodied AI compared to humanness and congruence.

The human designer and a cognitive design assistant are modeled as intelligent agents with shared goals and learning goals in Design Space Exploration (DSE), and the framework aims to advance the theory of human-AI collaborative design by identifying relevant factors for successful assistants and interactions.
Learning from emotional expressions in pre-play communication enhances human-AI negotiation outcomes by allowing participants to better understand their counterpart's preferences and limits.

This research introduces 'ORIBA', a customizable AI chatbot that enables illustrators to converse with their original characters, exploring innovative collaboration methods between humans and AI in creative fields.

Hybrid teams consisting of humans and autonomous systems can achieve improved performance by introducing an AI manager that learns to select the most suitable control agent through reinforcement learning while minimizing constraint violations.
Designing conversational components that facilitate human-agent negotiation by leveraging language to improve human users' likability and effectiveness in competitive negotiations.

Collaborative exploration of design spaces between human designers and AI cognitive assistants can be improved by prompting designers to reflect on their collaboration with the AI agent, leading to better design performance outcomes.
Collaborative ideation with a co-creative robot, such as Cobbie, is more effective than virtual agents in motivating exploration and generating creative ideas during early-stage design practices.
Our agent utilizes conversational and negotiation strategies mimicking human negotiations to maximize utility in simulated street vendor interactions.

Artificial prediction markets offer a promising approach to human-AI collaboration by enabling effective methods for combining human intuition and creativity with AI capabilities, particularly in complex tasks where traditional AI limitations prevail.
Humans can collaborate effectively with autonomous agents while maintaining autonomy when an agent provides implicit guidance, allowing humans to improve their own plans without feeling controlled.

Converging human intelligence with artificial intelligence systems can improve flood evacuation decision making by enhancing situational awareness, predicting risks, and optimizing response strategies.
The process of human learning shares common features with the process of machine learning, allowing for collaborative learning between humans and artificial intelligence.

The use of artificial intelligence is transforming health communication by enabling the collection and analysis of large amounts of data from wearable devices and mobile platforms, as well as delivering patient-centered care through human-AI interactions.

Humans and AI systems can achieve a level of collective intelligence that surpasses individual or isolated capabilities when their complementary strengths are synergized, but understanding and harnessing these interactions requires a multilayered approach to conceptualize the complex dynamics within human-AI collectives.

A prototype hybrid prediction market can facilitate meaningful human-AI collaboration by combining insights from both humans and AI agents to improve the accuracy of replicability estimates in published scientific work.
Users' attachment styles do not have a significant impact on their usage or engagement with ChatGPT, highlighting the need to address trust issues in AI systems.
AI should be utilized in the early stages of the design process to support discovering and defining design problems, rather than solely focusing on generating design solutions.

Access to conversational AI affects productivity and trust in users differently depending on user expertise, context, and type of questions, and understanding these factors is crucial for designing effective collaborations with these agents.
Developing intelligent agents capable of seamless coordination with humans by leveraging large language models to generate conventions that specify individual roles and actions before coordination.

Active learning query policies and uncertainty visualization significantly influence analyst trust in automated image classifiers, and designing interactive labeling systems can help mitigate overreliance and calibrate trust.

Attributing responsibility in human-AI interactions is not solely based on rational trust assessments, as participants tend to allocate excessive blame to multiple agents, with trust in the AI often serving as a proxy for trust in its developer.

Design fictions can be used to explore the potential consequences of operationalizing mutual theory of mind (MToM) between humans and AI agents, highlighting both the benefits of enhanced human-AI collaborations and the risks of problematic outcomes.

Zero-shot human-AI coordination can be improved by using a policy ensemble method to increase the diversity of partners and developing a context-aware approach that allows ego agents to analyze and adapt to novel human policies.
Manufacturing human-AI team interaction can be leveraged to construct more resilient cyber-physical-social systems by integrating AI-driven decision-making with human expertise and social awareness.
AI agents should be designed to effectively collaborate by capturing a model of their partners, achieving logarithmic regret in decentralized Multi-Armed Bandit problems.

Human-AI collaboration is essential for ensuring software system safety through the development of customized Large Language Model (LLM) agents that leverage prompt engineering, heuristic reasoning, and retrieval-augmented generation to analyze and address predefined safety concepts in real-time.

Existing approaches to designing interpretable agent behavior consider different measures of interpretability in isolation, but neglect the need for techniques that can effectively balance competing properties and account for open-world interactions with humans.
